description: From Middle French corrival, from Latin corrīvālis.

entries.meaning: Having rivaling claims; emulous; in rivalry.
examples: Not thinking, perhaps, that this would be, to erect a Power equal, and corrival with that of God Almighty  […]

entries.meaning: A fellow rival; a competitor; a rival.

examples: The Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster,The noble Westmoreland, and warlike Blunt;And many more corrivals and dear menOf estimation and command in arms.

verbs.description: corrival (third-person singular simple present corrivals, present participle corrivalling or corrivaling, simple past and past participle corrivalled or corrivaled)
